title: The 48-Hour Follow-Up Rule
description: Follow up with every new lead within 48 hours of first contact. Response rates drop dramatically after this window. A prompt, personalized follow-up signals professionalism and genuine interest.
suggestedActions: Send a personalized message referencing your conversation
Propose a specific date and time for a next meeting
Share one relevant educational resource

title: Warm Market Mapping
description: Systematically identify people in your existing network who might benefit from financial planning. Your warm market (friends, family, colleagues, community members) is the highest-conversion source of new leads.
suggestedActions: Review your contacts for people experiencing life events (new baby, home purchase, job change)
Ask existing clients for introductions after positive interactions
List 10 people you haven't spoken to in 6+ months and reach out

title: Referral Ask Timing
description: The best time to ask for referrals is right after delivering value — completing a policy review, resolving a claim, or receiving positive feedback. Frame the ask around helping others, not selling.
suggestedActions: After a positive client interaction, ask: 'Who else in your life might benefit from this kind of planning?'
Send a thank-you note after receiving a referral
Track which clients are your best referral sources and nurture those relationships

title: Stalled Lead Re-engagement
description: Leads that have gone quiet for 2+ weeks are not lost — they are waiting for the right prompt. A value-driven touchpoint (educational content, life event acknowledgment, or a simple check-in) can restart the conversation.
suggestedActions: Send a brief check-in message: 'I was thinking about our conversation and wanted to share this...'
Share a relevant article or educational post
Propose a low-pressure coffee or phone catch-up

title: Life Event Outreach
description: Life events (marriage, new baby, home purchase, job change, retirement, death in family) are the strongest triggers for financial planning conversations. Respond with genuine care first, then offer help when appropriate.
suggestedActions: Send a congratulations or sympathy message within 24 hours of learning about the event
Wait 1-2 weeks, then offer to review how the life change affects their financial plan
Create a note with the life event details for future reference

title: First 30-Day Mentoring Cadence
description: New recruits need daily contact in their first week, then every-other-day in weeks 2-4. This intensive mentoring period determines whether they stay or leave. Make each touchpoint short, encouraging, and action-oriented.
suggestedActions: Schedule daily 10-minute check-ins for the first week
Set up a shared study schedule for licensing exam preparation
Introduce the recruit to 2-3 supportive team members

title: Licensing Study Accountability
description: The licensing exam is the biggest dropout point for new recruits. Create accountability through regular study check-ins, practice tests, and milestone celebrations. Make it social, not solitary.
suggestedActions: Schedule weekly study progress check-ins
Organize group study sessions with other recruits
Celebrate milestones: 'You completed Chapter 5 — that is the hardest one!'

title: First-Sale Coaching
description: Getting a new agent to their first sale is critical for retention. Offer to sit in on their first few client meetings, provide scripts and talking points, and debrief after every appointment.
suggestedActions: Role-play the first client conversation before the meeting
Offer to attend the meeting as a silent support
Debrief within 24 hours: what went well, what to adjust

title: Team Meeting Rhythm
description: Regular team meetings build culture and accountability. Keep meetings short (30 min max), celebrate wins, share one learning, and end with action items. Consistency matters more than length.
suggestedActions: Schedule a recurring weekly team call at a consistent time
Start each meeting by recognizing one team member's win
End with each person stating their top priority for the week

title: Prospecting Power Hours
description: Block 1-2 hours daily for focused prospecting (calls, messages, outreach). Treat this time as sacred — no admin, no email, no distractions. The agents who prospect consistently outperform those who binge-prospect.
suggestedActions: Schedule a daily prospecting block on your calendar
Prepare your call/message list the night before
Track how many contacts you make during each block

title: 80/20 Client Focus
description: Roughly 20% of your clients generate 80% of your referrals and revenue. Identify your top-tier clients and ensure they receive disproportionate attention — quarterly reviews, birthday calls, life event follow-ups.
suggestedActions: Identify your top 10 clients by referral generation and policy value
Schedule quarterly personal check-ins with each
Send personalized messages on birthdays and anniversaries

title: Deep Work Protection
description: Financial planning analysis, proposal preparation, and content creation require focused, uninterrupted time. Block 90-minute deep work sessions and defend them. These are revenue-generating activities.
suggestedActions: Schedule 2-3 deep work blocks per week on your calendar
Batch similar tasks: all proposals on Tuesday, all reviews on Thursday
Turn off notifications during deep work blocks

title: Batch Administrative Tasks
description: Administrative work (data entry, filing, compliance paperwork) expands to fill available time. Batch all admin into one or two dedicated blocks per week instead of doing it throughout the day.
suggestedActions: Designate Friday afternoon as admin time
Create a running list of admin tasks throughout the week
Set a timer and work through the list without switching to other tasks

title: Educational Post Formula
description: The most effective social media posts for financial professionals follow a simple formula: Problem → Insight → Action. Start with a relatable financial challenge, share one non-obvious insight, then invite engagement.
suggestedActions: Draft a post: 'Most people don't realize [insight]. Here is what you can do about it...'
Use plain language, no jargon
End with a question to invite comments

title: Consistency Over Virality
description: Posting 2-3 times per week consistently outperforms sporadic viral attempts. Your network needs to see you regularly to think of you when they need financial planning. Schedule posts in advance.
suggestedActions: Plan next week's 2-3 posts today
Alternate between educational content, personal stories, and client wins (anonymized)
Post at consistent times when your audience is active

title: Client Success Stories
description: Anonymized client success stories are the most powerful content you can share. They demonstrate real results without making claims. Frame them as 'a client recently...' and focus on the outcome, not the product.
suggestedActions: Write up one recent client success (anonymized, no specific numbers)
Focus on the emotional outcome: peace of mind, confidence, relief
Ask the client if they would be willing to give a testimonial

title: Seasonal Content Hooks
description: Seasonal events create natural content opportunities: tax season, open enrollment, New Year resolutions, back-to-school, graduation. Plan your content calendar around these predictable hooks.
suggestedActions: Look at the calendar for upcoming seasonal events in the next 30 days
Draft 1-2 posts connecting the season to financial planning
Reference timely topics your clients are already thinking about

title: Communication Channel Matching
description: Different people prefer different communication channels. Pay attention to how contacts respond — if someone always replies to texts within an hour but ignores emails for days, text them. Match the channel to the person.
suggestedActions: Review your recent interactions with key contacts — which channel gets the fastest response?
Note preferred channels in SAM for each important contact
When in doubt, use the channel they most recently used to contact you

title: Best Day and Time for Outreach
description: Track when your outreach gets the best response rates. Many financial professionals find Tuesday-Thursday mid-morning and early evening work best. Avoid Monday mornings and Friday afternoons.
suggestedActions: Review your recent successful conversations — when did they happen?
Schedule important outreach during your proven best windows
Test different times and track response rates over a month

title: Referral Source Tracking
description: Know where your leads come from. Track referral sources (which client, which event, which post) so you can double down on what works. Your best future leads will come from the same sources as your best current clients.
suggestedActions: For every new lead, note how they found you
Review your pipeline — which sources produced clients who actually closed?
Invest more time in your top 2-3 referral sources

title: Upline Consultation
description: Your upline trainer, supervisor, or field coach has seen your challenges before. Schedule regular consultations — not just when things go wrong. They can help you spot blind spots in your business before they become problems.
suggestedActions: Schedule a monthly check-in with your upline or field trainer
Come prepared with specific questions, not just general updates
Ask for feedback on your client approach and recruiting strategy

title: Weekly Goal Review
description: Spend 15 minutes each Sunday evening reviewing last week's goals and setting next week's priorities. This simple habit keeps you focused and prevents drift. Write down your top 3 priorities for the week.
suggestedActions: Review this week: what did you accomplish? What carried over?
Set 3 specific, measurable goals for next week
Create a note in SAM with your weekly plan

title: Personal Development Investment
description: The most successful agents invest in their own growth: reading, attending training, practicing presentations, learning new financial concepts. Dedicate at least 30 minutes daily to professional development.
suggestedActions: Schedule a daily 30-minute learning block
Attend your team's training sessions and take notes
Read one industry article per day and note key takeaways

title: Networking Event Preparation
description: Before any networking event, prepare 2-3 conversation openers that are not about insurance. Ask about people's work, families, recent events. Listen more than you talk. Exchange contact info and follow up within 48 hours.
suggestedActions: Research the event and likely attendees beforehand
Prepare 2-3 genuine conversation starters unrelated to your business
Set a goal: meet 5 new people and exchange contact information
